title: Clinical Opiate Withdrawal Scale (COWS) for Opiate Withdrawal
description: Quantifies severity of opiate withdrawal symptoms using 11 clinical criteria to guide treatment decisions and assess withdrawal progression

parameters.name: resting_pulse_rate
parameters.description: Resting pulse rate in beats per minute

parameters.name: bone_joint_aches
parameters.description: Bone or joint aches and pains

parameters.name: gi_upset
parameters.description: GI upset (stomach cramps, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea)

result.name: cows_score
result.description: Total COWS score indicating withdrawal severity

ranges.interpretation: No withdrawal treatment necessary. Monitor for symptom development.
Mild withdrawal symptoms. Consider supportive care and comfort medications.
Moderate withdrawal symptoms. Pharmacologic treatment indicated. Consider buprenorphine induction.
Moderately severe withdrawal symptoms. Medication-assisted treatment strongly recommended.
Severe withdrawal symptoms. Immediate medical intervention and intensive treatment required.

references: Wesson DR, Ling W. The Clinical Opiate Withdrawal Scale (COWS). Journal of Psychoactive Drugs. 2003;35(2):253-259. doi:10.1080/02791072.2003.10400007

Tompkins DA, Bigelow GE, Harrison JA, Johnson RE, Fudala PJ, Strain EC. Concurrent validation of the Clinical Opiate Withdrawal Scale (COWS) and single-item indices against the Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol-revised (CIWA-Ar). Drug Alcohol Depend. 2009;105(1-2):154-159.
formula: Sum of individual symptom scores (range 0-48 points)
notes: Developed in 2003 by Wesson and Ling for standardized assessment of opiate withdrawal
Validated in 2009 using naloxone challenges on opioid-dependent volunteers
Useful for guiding buprenorphine/naloxone initiation to prevent precipitated withdrawal
Should be administered by trained healthcare professionals
Scores guide treatment decisions including medication-assisted treatment (MAT)
Assessment should be repeated regularly during withdrawal management
Clinical judgment should always accompany numerical scores
Tool is in the public domain and widely available from addiction medicine organizations
